author: Peter Hughes
title: Why you should ditch the Med in favour of Scandinavia this summer
text:
Articles Why you should ditch the Med in favour of Scandinavia this summer Defy convention, forget the Med and opt for the wild Bohuslän coast of Sweden, says Peter Hughes Credit: HENRIK TRYGG Peter Hughes , Travel writer  05pm 
T here is a law in the physics of travel which states that when the British are partially or completely immersed in leisure, they head south. As predictably as Newton’s apple, a Briton in search of relaxation gravitates to lower latitudes and higher temperatures. 
It may not be as immutable as Archimedes’ Principle but it applies nine times out of 10. Which is a shame: it’s so limiting. Just for a change, counter the intuition, buck the trend and go north. Head for those lands that are thinly populated and thickly forested, with long summer days but less need for sun block – and which, crucially, are not in conflict. The 15 best alternatives to another predictable Mediterranean holiday 
Some, like Sweden, are even outside the Eurozone. Since last summer the pound has bought just over five per cent fewer Swedish kroner compared with some 20 per cent fewer euros. So a dish of cod au gratin, which cost £15.22 in Sweden last May, costs only about another 80p today. Who knows? Cool could turn out to be the new cool. Which is how I found myself on a flight to Gothenburg to spend six days touring the west coast by car. Trendy Gothenburg Credit: ALAMY 
Gothenburg is Scandi-blanc. Free from the oppression of high-rises, it’s like a city with the roof off. I had one evening there before picking up my hire car and made straight for Haga, the “old town”. Haga Nygata is a long street of elderly buildings which, if they are not timber, are made of stone to look like timber. It is not overtly touristy or, if it is, they are Swedish tourists looking for hats and light fittings as much as delicatessens and cafés. It was there, at Sjöbaren, a sort of gastropub with wood-planked walls, that I had the cod. In retrospect, I wish I had chosen “Fillet of Witch”. Sounds spellbinding. The Gothenburg archipelago Credit: ALAMY 
Sweden’s wild west – the Bohuslän coast – is a free, breezy shore of sea and rock running from Gothenburg to the Norwegian border. It’s only about 100 miles long but is a complex puzzle of straits and islands, inlets and crusty shorelines of low, coarse cliffs. 
On the water, flattened skerries are strewn like maritime cobbles. Some are as smooth as buttocks, others scraped and abraded by glaciers as they dragged themselves across the landscape 10,000 years ago. If Norway’s coast was slashed by nature, Sweden’s was crushed. Sweden’s wild west – the Bohuslän coast – is a free, breezy shore of sea and rock running from Gothenburg to the Norwegian border Credit: Slow Images/Slow Images 
The coast is epitomised by the Weather Isles. The Väderöarna Islands, as the guidebooks have them, are an archipelago of 365 lumps of curvaceous rock. There are few trees but there is colour: daubs of orange algae, clumps of purple sea thrift in spring and settlements of blood-red houses, timbered and tiled. Even the rock is pinkish. 
They get their name from having “the hardest weather in Sweden”, Mikael Hansson said as we sped 35 minutes by powerful catamaran out to his guesthouse on Storö. It’s an old pilot’s house; most buildings are. 
Storö was a pilot station before the demise of coastal shipping in the Sixties. But their lookout hut is still there, perched on giant concrete legs, a tiny shed which was manned 24 hours a day. The pilots were a fractious bunch. Even the two families that shared the guesthouse feuded. Today it’s more civilised, with a decent restaurant and rooms so popular they are booked for New Year until 2024. 
Around Lyckorna, on the mainland, the coast is more genteel, tamed over 150 years by grand waterfront houses with towers and verandas, their own docks and sometimes boathouses. 
I stayed in one, Villa Sjötorp. Built of wood in 1901 by a paper-mill owner as a neo-gothic summer house, it is now a 14-bedroom hotel. White, with a green roof and three pointy gables decorated with fretwork, it has a fairy-tale quality. The lawn, shaded by a colossal tree, plunges to a private beach. Rooms may be homely but the food is not. At dinner, the dining room was packed with gourmet Swedes who had driven miles for the five-course tasting menu. 
Two minutes up the road at Ljungskile, Janne Bank runs “seafood safaris” to harvest mussels. I joined him on Märta, a 36ft former fishing boat painted scarlet. The mussels grow on 10 submerged rigs, each an eighth of a mile long, marked by drum-shaped floats. Eider ducks are reckoned to snaffle a good 55lb of mussels a month. There are plenty left: each rig carries 200 tons. Märta tilted 10 degrees as her crane strained to haul bunches of mussels on board. Ashore, Janne steamed them with diced vegetables in sparkling wine in a pan big enough to signal satellites. Lunches don’t come much fresher. On to Fjällbacka, a village jammed on to a shelf of land beneath a 240ft granite cliff. It’s massive, but look closely and bits of it are discreetly shored up with concrete buttresses. The waterfront is spiny with timber jetties, behind which rises a collage of candy-coloured houses, garnet, vanilla and ochre. The smallest, old boathouses, are not much bigger than sheds. It’s not fashionable enough to be smart but too prosperous to be scruffy. There are few trees but there is colour: daubs of orange algae, clumps of purple sea thrift in spring and settlements of blood-red houses, timbered and tiled Credit: ALAMY 
Fjällbacka has an extra patina of chic because, for a quarter of a century it was the summer home of Ingrid Bergman, goddess of 20th-century cinema. She was born in Stockholm but Fjällbacka, or rather Dannholmen Island, about a mile offshore, became the part of Sweden she called home. Here she could flee the relentless attention attracted by a three-time Oscar winner. For 24 years she spent her summers on Dannholmen. Her third husband, the impresario Lars Schmidt, bought it for her in 1957. In Fjällbacka’s village square, named after her, there’s a bust and photographs of her family holidays. In several there appears a young man called Lasse Lundberg. Now 80, he used to own the village restaurant and sailing school. I met him through a moment of traveller’s serendipity. 
I had retreated to the village pizza restaurant for a brief respite from fish. My waitress, Berith Haj Khalifa, wife of the Tunisian chef, remembered serving the star in the Fjällbacka bakery. “But the person you need to talk to is Lasse Lundberg,” she said. 
Lasse taught Ingrid to sail. “That was how we met,” he recalled. “She phoned one day in 1968 and said, 'I want to learn to sail because Lars has bought a boat’.” It was the start of a long friendship. Lasse often stayed on the island. “She didn’t want to talk about her films,” he said. “She was so down to earth.” One of his most potent memories is of helping her wash up. Fjällbacka Credit: ANDREA PUCCI 
Dannholmen became a bolt-hole for the A-list of the day. Lasse was their boatman. Diana Ross was a guest; Marcello Mastroianni and Roman Polanski were frequent visitors, as was Alfred Hitchcock. “Because of his size it was difficult to get out of the boat.” 
In the summer of 1982, Lasse and Ingrid had dinner. At her insistence they ate crevettes. “She said, 'I want to do something for Fjällbacka.’ I said, 'You have done so much already’.” Two weeks later she died in London on her 67th birthday. Her ashes were scattered in the sea off Dannholmen. 
There’s another display of domestic images about 10 miles north of Fjällbacka. They are 3,500 years old. The Tanum rock carvings comprise the biggest and most important collection of Bronze Age art in Scandinavia and are on Unesco’s World Heritage list. There are at least 1,500 sites and 40,000 engravings, little Lowry-like stick figures scratched into beds of granite, some controversially picked out in red paint to make them more photogenic. I saw the ones at Vitlycke, where there is a museum. All Bronze Age life is here, shared in prehistoric Instagrams: ships, chariots, warfare and sex. A prequel to Scandi-noir. 
My final stop was at Bjertorp Slott, a domestic castle built at Kvänum in 1914 for a wealthy diplomat. It became a hotel in the Eighties but kept its striking Art Nouveau detailing in marble, mahogany and an elaborate plaster ceiling. Läckö Castle Credit: ALAMY 
This is something it has in common with Läckö Castle, but Läckö dates from 1298 and was a proper fortification, although it was given a fancy Baroque makeover in the early 17th century. Most of the artistry went upwards: in one room a dozen chubby cherubs actually dangle from the ceiling. The building is massive. Standing four square on the shore of Lake Värnen, painted white, turreted and domed, it’s half fantasy, half forbidding. It could be Disney’s take on Colditz. 
My guide began one of the regular tours for English speakers with a kindly admonition: “Most things here are 300 to 400 years old, so try not to touch them too much. I know it can be hard.” That’s Sweden for you – kind, relaxed, friendly, different, and sometimes irresistible, all reasons to head north. Essentials 
Peter Hughes travelled with Best Served Scandinavia (020 7664 2241; best-served.co.uk ) which can tailor-make a seven-night self-drive Gothenburg & The West tour of Sweden from £1,240 per person (based on two sharing). The price includes return flights, two nights b & b in Gothenburg, six days car hire, one night half board at Villa Sjötorp, two nights b & b at Stora Hotel in Fjällbacka and two nights half board at Bjertorp Castle. Further information from West Sweden Tourist Board ( vastsverige.com ). 10 northern trips worth skipping the Med for 1. Cycling in Denmark 
Flat back roads and well-marked paths combined with historic towns and sandy beaches make the Danish island of Zealand relaxing cycling terrain. A seven-night, self-guided tour called Denmark’s Largest Island starts and finishes in the capital Copenhagen, covering more than 200 miles. Highlights include the medieval town of Koge, a Viking ring fortress at Trelleborg, the fjords of Roskilde and Copenhagen itself with its gardens, palace, cafés and acclaimed restaurants. 
From £747, including b&b accommodation and luggage transfer. Flights and bike hire cost extra. Departures from June to August. Freedom Treks (01273 224066; freedomtreks.co.uk ). Copenhagen 2. Short break in Reykjavik 
Four nights in Iceland’s vibrant and compact capital gives visitors enough time to explore the city’s harbour, parliament building and Hallgrimskirkja church – and get a taste of the island’s extraordinary landscapes. Combine the nightlife and city buzz with a trip to the island’s southern shores, a half-day whale-watching trip, a dip in the famous Blue Lagoon and a Golden Circle tour including the dramatic Gullfoss waterfalls and erupting Strokkur geyser. 
From £959, including accommodation, breakfast and flights. Departures from May to September 2017. Riviera Travel (01283 888204; rivieratravel.co.uk ). Gullfoss Credit: aaron_huang86 - Fotolia 3. Lakeside self-catering in Lapland 
Summer days are at their longest north of the Arctic Circle in Swedish Lapland and in this remote region you can find lakeside or woodland hideaways which are ideal for tranquil, outdoor holidays. Eight comfortable log cabins at Arrenjarka, on the shores of Lake Saggat, sleep six or eight people and are clustered around a central reception with shop and restaurant. Activities include forest walks, hiking trails and fishing. 
From £1,025 per person based on full occupancy of an eight-bed cabin including flights and hire car. Departures from June 16 to September 30. Simply Sweden (01427 700115; simplysweden.co.uk ). Best countries 4. Riding in Iceland 
Horse riding is a good way to see the most inaccessible and beautiful mountain and coastal regions of Iceland. A four- or six-night itinerary called “Iceland – Snæfellsnes” uses the country’s small indigenous horses as transport, and the ground is mostly covered at a tolt (fast trot) with demanding four- to eight-hour days in the saddle. Guests stay at Stori-Kalfalækur Farm, which offers simple farmhouse accommodation in shared rooms. 
From £1,193, including accommodation and meals on the ride. Flights are not included. Departures between June and August. In The Saddle (01299 272997; inthesaddle.com ). 5. Wilderness tour in Finland 
This tour offers the opportunity to explore the spectacular northernmost reaches of the country on an eight-day Wildlife and Wilderness self-drive itinerary starting at Kajaani and finishing in Rovaniemi. Driving through the taiga forests and national parks close to the Russian border, optional excursions include bear-watching safaris, and visits to the Second World War battle sites at Raate and the rock paintings at Varikalliot. Other activities include canoeing, fishing and hiking. 
From £1,265, including accommodation, some meals, car hire and flights. Departures between May and September. Regent Holidays (0203 733 8979; regent-holidays.co.uk ). Skip France in favour of Finland this summer Credit: ALAMY 6. Summer Icehotel experience in Sweden 
New for this year, guests can experience the Icehotel 365 in Jukkasjarvi throughout the summer months with solar power used to maintain the sub-zero temperatures. A new four-night fly-drive holiday includes two nights in an ice room plus two nights in quirky forest canopy rooms at the Treehotel in Lulea. Optional activities include fishing, canoeing and horse riding. 
From £1,329, including accommodation with some meals, flights and car hire. Departures from July to September. Discover the World (01737 214291; discover-the-world.co.uk/icehotel ). The first year-round Icehotel is now open 7. Self-drive tour of the Faroe Islands 
This archipelago of 18 islands with their dramatic coastlines, rich bird life and traditional Nordic culture lies 200 miles off the Scottish coast in the North Atlantic. A seven-night Classic Circle tour starts on the island of Vagar with its sea-sculpted rock stacks and continues to the small town of Eidi on Eysturoy for mountain views. Stay in the capital, Torshavn, to visit Skopun. 
From £1,685, including accommodation, breakfasts, hire car and flights. Departures from April to October. Nordic Experience (01206 708888; nordicexperience.co.uk ). The Faroe Islands 8. Music festival in Finland 
A six-night itinerary encompassing Helsinki and the 18th Sibelius Festival in Lahti starts in the Finnish capital with tours of its cathedral, art collections and sights connected to country’s famous 19th-century composer Jean Sibelius. A four-night stay in Lahti includes concerts by the Lahti Symphony Orchestra and the Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra in celebration of the centenary of the country’s independence, performed in the Sibelius Hall near Lake Vesijarvi. 
From £2,749, including accommodation, most meals and flights. Departure on August 28 2017. Kirker Holidays (020 7593 2284; kirkerholidays.com ). 9. Walking trails in Greenland 
Though summer days can be mild and sunny, the climate here is unpredictable – so be aware that this new, 12-day Icefjords and Villages of Greenland tour through rugged terrain can be challenging if the weather is poor. The itinerary, too, is not for the faint-hearted, involving up to seven hours of walking each day through dramatic glacial landscapes and across Ammassalik Island to Tasiilaq, on an Inuit trail with simple accommodation in hostels, village houses and refuges. 
From £3,095, including accommodation and most meals. Flights are not included. Departures in July and August. KE Adventure Travel (01768 773966; keadventure.com ). The coast of Greenland Credit: ALAMY 10. Escorted tour in the Baltics 
Dr Jeremy Howard, an author and a lecturer at the University of St Andrews, is no stranger to the Baltic states and makes a highly informed host on a trip to the region. He gives some intriguing insights into the diverse history, language and culture of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia on this 14-day Art, Architecture and History tour of the Baltic nations. The tour takes in the country capitals – Tallinn, Riga and Vilnius, combined with national parks and medieval towns. 
From £3,710, including accommodation with most meals and flights. Departure on July 21 2017. Martin Randall Travel (020 8742 3355; martinrandall.com ).
